item.title: Once in Guantánamo, Afghan Now Leads War Against Taliban and ISIS
item.description: Officials describe Hajji Ghalib as a fiercely effective fighter against the insurgency, and the American military supports his men with airstrikes.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hajji Ghalib, the governor of Achin District in the province of Nangarhar in eastern Afghanistan, was once imprisoned in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

item.title: Israel to Open Diplomatic Office in United Arab Emirates
item.description: The mission at the International Renewable Energy Agency will be the first time in more than a decade that there will be an official Israeli presence in the Persian Gulf.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: As Pope Francis’ Visit Nears, Central African Republic Violence Rises
item.description: The United Nations warned that a resurgence of violence has driven tens of thousands of people from their homes and threatens humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: France, 2 Weeks After Paris Attacks, Observes National Day of Mourning
item.description: At an official ceremony, President François Hollande described the victims as “130 laughs that we won’t hear anymore, 130 voices that went quiet forever.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Finding a Path Back to Iraq, and Toward Securing Women’s Freedom
item.description: Yanar Mohammed runs a secret network of safe houses in the country meant to give women a second chance, but running them did so for her.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yanar Mohammed in Toronto on Thursday. She is a co-founder of the Organization of Women’s Freedom in Iraq, a secret network of safe houses in her native country.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Cartoon: Chappatte on the Paris Climate Talks
item.description: Two weeks after terrorist attacks, Paris is preparing to host a global conference on climate change.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Thousands Protest Arrest of 2 Turkish Journalists on Spying Charges
item.description: Can Dundar, the editor in chief of the newspaper Cumhuriyet, and Erdem Gul, its Ankara bureau chief, were charged with divulging state secrets and being members of a terrorist group.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Turkey Seeks to Ease Tensions Over Shooting Down of Russian Jet
item.description: Ankara said airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria had been suspended as it sought a solution, possibly at the Paris climate talks next week.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and his French counterpart, Franois Hollande, in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Lu Yang on Art, ‘Uterus Man’ and Living Life on the Web
item.description: The Shanghai-born new media artist has produced a series of boundary-pushing multimedia works that explore neuroscience, mortality and religion.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: "Lu Yang Delusional Mandala," Ms. Lu's recent solo exhibition at Beijing Commune, included a video (pictured), crystal sculptures and an installation to simulate a "delusion" in which Ms. Lu destroys her own body and work.

item.title: Sinosphere: Statement by Chinese Rights Campaigner Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
item.description: Yang Maodong, known as Guo Feixiong, wrote down his thoughts in anticipation of the ruling, and the document was released by his wife.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Yang Maodong, also known as Guo Feixiong

item.title: Pope Francis, in Nairobi Slum, Denounces ‘New Forms of Colonialism’
item.description: He said that “countries are frequently pressured to adopt policies typical of the culture of waste, like those aimed at lowering the birthrate.”
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited the Kangemi slum on the outskirts of Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, on Friday.

item.title: Chinese Rights Advocate Known as Guo Feixiong Convicted of Unexpected New Charge
item.description: The addition of new charge, “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” means that he will spend an additional two years in prison, according to his lawyers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Yang Maodong, a veteran protester better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong.

item.title: Paris Slowly Coming to Terms With a New Vulnerability
item.description: The city wants to get past the lost tourism and uncertainties that followed the Nov. 13 attacks. But as candles burn low and bouquets wilt, a certain shock lingers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memorials left at the monument in the Place de la République in Paris after the Nov. 13 attacks.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Europe the Unready
item.description: The hope for a growing European unity has suffered setbacks amid terrorism, the refugee crisis and financial challenges.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

item.title: Gunmen Strike Shiite Mosque in Bangladesh
item.description: Gunmen opened fire during evening prayers at the mosque, killing one person and wounding three, in the second recent attack on Bangladesh’s tiny Shiite population.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: North and South Korea to Hold High-Level Talks Next Month
item.description: The talks, to be led by a vice minister from each side, are intended to ease tensions and improve relations on the divided Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Moldova: 13 Accused of Plotting Attacks
item.description: The Moldovan police said Thursday that they had detained 13 people suspected of being members of a paramilitary group accused of planning to attack cities.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cellphone Recording Leads to Arrest of Brazilian Senator on Obstruction Charges
item.description: Delcídio do Amaral, an ally of President Dilma Rousseff, was charged with impeding an investigation into Brazil’s state-owned oil company.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: River Polluted After Dam Burst
item.description: Illegal levels of arsenic and mercury polluted a river in the days after a dam burst at an iron ore mine this month.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Anti-Insurgency Goal Extended
item.description: Nigeria’s military cannot meet the president’s December deadline to crush Boko Haram’s Islamist uprising.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
